content:
Try this:

- go to TB menu > Settings > General 

- scroll all the way down and click the 'Config editor' button on the right 
- click 'Accept the risk and continue' 
- search for accessibility.force_disabled > change the value to 1 > click the check mark 
- restart TB
creator: siffemoz

content: Ed, I did not see any "accept the risk and continue," but I did the search, changed the number to 1, restarted TB, repeated the procedure and saw the number 1 was still showing. Now I'll wait and hope it doesn't freeze again. Thank you for this help. Jonelle
creator: jinkem

content:
If your Hotmail password is correct but Thunderbird still won’t connect, the issue is usually with authentication settings. Make sure you’re using OAuth2 for authentication instead of the basic password option. Also double-check the IMAP settings:

Incoming server: imap-mail.outlook.com, port 993, SSL/TLS

Outgoing server: smtp-mail.outlook.com, port 587, STARTTLS

Sometimes enabling “Allow apps that use modern authentication” in your Microsoft account security settings is also required. After that, try removing and re-adding the account in Thunderbird.

For more troubleshooting tips and resources, you can also check: http://example.com https://the-deemix.pro
creator: zahoorasad830

content:
it could be that hotmail does not use your password, other than in the initial setup. It could be that Hotmail used cookies and lots of folk follow poor advice from their security software and disable them so the setup does not work without them. In may be you antivirus/malware tool/spn makes setting up an account impossible with it active.

What your specific issue is, is really a matter of working through a load of possibilities to determine which actually applies to you.

  1. Do you have an antivirus product other than defender? (Norton sell a product that can almost be expected to cripple the Thunderbird setup wizard a state of affairs they have apparently been happy with for around a decade and several corporate reinventions of the parent company)
  2. Do you have an VPN? These also offer extreme issues with setting up a mail account. Many providers simply block attempts to set up an account while using them as it appears to them you have been hacked. Your phone is in say Islamabad and you VPN says you are in Anchorage. Something they treat as a clue everything is not as it should be.
  3. Can you connect to this web site in a browser. autoconfig.thunderbird.net/v1.1/hotmail.com
  4. Can you connect to the Thunderbird addons website from within Thunderbird? appmenu > addons and themes
  5. Search for import in the search box. Does the ImportExportToolsNG addon appear in the tab with an add to Thunderbird button?

All of these things offer clues as to what the issue might be. None of them is a solution because this is something specific to your computer, not mine. I can add a hotmail account without any issues at all.

content: SOLVED. Found on my Gmail online account a Labels/IMAP folder marked 'Drafts'. Deleted this and this solved my duplication issue.

content:
More information, please. What's you operating system? How did you make your profile backup - did you use Thunderbird's Export feature, or did you make it manually? What do you use to "unzip" it - does your OS have a built-in unzipper, or do you use a 3rd-party utility?

I suggest you unzip it to a temporary folder (anywhere, even on your Desktop) so you can examine it to see if it looks right. Then you can move it into its final resting place.

content:
I've been told that Thunderbird's Export feature can't handle profiles larger than 2 GB. Is yours that size or larger? It sounds like the zip file is corrupt.

I have never actually used Thunderbird's Export feature, but if I understand how it works, you shouldn't unzip the resulting file - you use the Import feature on the new machine to import the zipped file. Thunderbird will take care of upzipping it and placing it in the proper place. It looks like you can also import directly from an original unzipped profile, if it's accessible.

I prefer to make periodic manual backups my my profile, so I can recover most of my email in things go bad, like a disk crash, or for migrating to another computer. Can you still get to your old setup with the original profile? If so and you'd like to try it manually I'll type up some instructions.

content:
rainbowheron said
I have 4 emails on the same server, which use IMAP, so there is no way for me to adjust any msg retrieval settings, because they don't exist. Surprisingly,

Here are just those settings you say do not exist for one of my IMAP Gmail accounts in the current ESR release. (I also have the same information in the developer daily build so it has not gone away in the latest releases)

one of these 4 emails actually does work in sending & receiving, but I got different error with it, just now! I also have one gmail affected by this original 2 year old problem, as well.

I am just another Thunderbird user. so unless you can share the actual error message the best I can do is guess.

Closing program, restarting computer, and downloading TB updates all do not work. I uninstalled/reinstalled TB, and all of my profiles & emails were surprisingly intact with no deletes (yes, I backed them up in another folder first), and the problem persists upon reinstall of TB, on the exact same emails as the original problem. Antivirus & firewalls are off. Server said it wasn't them. I'm using Windows 11, McAfee antivirus, and the newest TB dld is Eclipse. >/blockquote> Uninstall McAfee and see if things get better. There is a host of manual things you have to do to make McAfee work with Thunderbird. Back in 2012 they released a new heuristics engine (Just a short time after Intel bought the company from it's founder John McAfee. In my opinion that was the beginning of the end for McAfee. They have been crashing Thunderbird, blocking mail and generally not doing a good job of allowing folk to use their mail client ever since. There is no distinct alphanumeric error message for the oldest problem, just the usual "Login to server with username failed. Retry/Enter New Password/Cancel." All passwords are correct. None of my passwords are "saved" in the TB program, and I'm having trouble locating where to tell it to do otherwise. Screencap and copy/paste attempts to grab second error message failed, but it looked like "RETR failed, one message expunged." So far, it's a one-time error, which I can live with. All emails for that ONE working email are fine. When I attempt to sign into Google, it takes me to a troubleshooting page https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/32050?hl=en asking me to clear cache & cookies, if I'm using Chrome (which I'm not), instead of just a login to retrieve my gmail.

That like is very clear in stating Clear cache & cookies

When you use a browser, like Chrome, it saves some information from websites in its cache and cookies. Clearing them fixes certain problems, like loading or formatting issues on sites.

Funny thing, ALL browsers (including Thunderbird) have a cache. Google offered advice on how to clear the cache in the browser they make. You are not "just a login to retrieve my gmail" Gmail uses the oauth authentication method, this method requires a browser to set up and provide the initial authentication as well as cookies. oAuth is at it's heart a browser specific authentication method which Thunderbird was able to meet by leveraging the inherited parts of the Firefox browser from the Mozilla platform on which it is built.

See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-clear-firefox-cache for clearing the cache in Firefox.

In Thunderbird go to the appmenu, select help and then the troubleshooting information. Then press the clear startup cache button on the top right of the tab.

My emails have been sitting on the servers for 2 YEARS and I am at my wits' end - please help!!!

You say 2 years. I mentioned the oauth authentication requirements for gmail. That commenced to be a requirement from May 30, 2022 so I would assume your authentication method is oAuth, as there was an automatic conversion. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20 However as you apparently have not found the fetch timing on the same pane as the authentication method I think we should check that this is not the issue all along. Is it set to OAuth2 as shown in the image I posted?
